clusters.title: Medicaid chief’s claim $1bn is spent on healthcare for ‘illegal immigrants’ is false, say experts
clusters.neutral_headline: Experts Dispute Claim About Medicaid Spending on Immigrants

items.title: Medicaid chief’s claim $1bn is spent on healthcare for ‘illegal immigrants’ is false, say experts
items.standfirst: Mehmet Oz made claim about audits, but experts say he misidentified routine administrative errorsThe administrator for the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS), Mehmet Oz, recently claimed that an audit revealed “more than $1bn of federal taxpayer dollars were being spent on funding Medicaid for illegal immigrants”, but experts say the audits were unrelated to immigration, and that rhetoric like this could make immigrant families – regardless of legal status – afraid to seek necessary medical care.Leo Cuello, a research professor at Georgetown University’s Center for Children and Families, noted that he had not “seen what this audit is”, but “based on the reporting, it appears that it is related to administrative errors in state claiming for matching funds, which is a relatively common occurrence, and which CMS monitors closely as they should”. Continue reading...
items.content: Mehmet Oz made claim about audits, but experts say he misidentified routine administrative errorsThe administrator for the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS), Mehmet Oz, recently claimed that an audit revealed “more than $1bn of federal taxpayer dollars were being spent on funding Medicaid for illegal immigrants”, but experts say the audits were unrelated to immigration, and that rhetoric like this could make immigrant families – regardless of legal status – afraid to seek necessary medical care.Leo Cuello, a research professor at Georgetown University’s Center for Children and Families, noted that he had not “seen what this audit is”, but “based on the reporting, it appears that it is related to administrative errors in state claiming for matching funds, which is a relatively common occurrence, and which CMS monitors closely as they should”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Mehmet Oz claimed over $1 billion in Medicaid funds went to illegal immigrants.
Experts say the audits cited were related to administrative errors, not immigration.
Administrative errors in state claiming for funds are relatively common occurrences.
Experts worry rhetoric could deter immigrants from seeking medical care.
The CMS closely monitors administrative errors in state claiming for funds.

clusters.title: Coffee may protect people against irregular heartbeats, US study finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Coffee Consumption May Protect Against Irregular Heartbeats

items.title: Coffee may protect people against irregular heartbeats, US study finds
items.standfirst: Trial’s findings go against common beliefs that people with atrial fibrillation should avoid caffeinated coffeeDrinking coffee may protect people against irregular heartbeats, despite the conventional wisdom to the contrary, according to a new study.The Does Eliminating Coffee Avoid Fibrillation (Decaf) clinical trial found 200 patients with persistent irregular heartbeats had a “significantly” lower risk of the condition recurring if they belonged to the study group that was allocated coffee consumption rather than the one abstaining from it – 47% to 64%. Continue reading...
items.content: Trial’s findings go against common beliefs that people with atrial fibrillation should avoid caffeinated coffeeDrinking coffee may protect people against irregular heartbeats, despite the conventional wisdom to the contrary, according to a new study.The Does Eliminating Coffee Avoid Fibrillation (Decaf) clinical trial found 200 patients with persistent irregular heartbeats had a “significantly” lower risk of the condition recurring if they belonged to the study group that was allocated coffee consumption rather than the one abstaining from it – 47% to 64%. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A study found coffee may protect against irregular heartbeats.
The study involved 200 patients with persistent irregular heartbeats.
Patients allocated coffee consumption had a lower risk of recurrence.
The coffee group showed a significantly lower risk of the condition recurring.
The study's findings contradict common beliefs about coffee and atrial fibrillation.

clusters.title: As a palliative care specialist, I’ve witnessed the human tragedy of our end-of-life care crisis | Rachel Clarke
clusters.neutral_headline: Palliative Care Crisis Highlighted in End-of-Life Care

items.title: As a palliative care specialist, I’ve witnessed the human tragedy of our end-of-life care crisis | Rachel Clarke
items.standfirst: While the government debates assisted dying, palliative care is an afterthought. And many more people face death without the care and support they needA baby, in Britain, in 2025, takes its stuttering final breaths. All deaths in infancy are harrowing. But the fact that this particular death might have been prevented – had neonatal care not depended so heavily on charity, had the NHS not failed to fund more than two-thirds of the healthcare babies need – is unforgivable.Mercifully, the dystopian healthcare scenario I’ve just described does not exist in the UK today. Although paediatric care is undeniably overstretched, it is at least regarded as a core, bedrock NHS service.Dr Rachel Clarke is an NHS specialist in palliative medicine and the winner of the 2025 Women’s prize for nonfiction Continue reading...
items.content: While the government debates assisted dying, palliative care is an afterthought. And many more people face death without the care and support they needA baby, in Britain, in 2025, takes its stuttering final breaths. All deaths in infancy are harrowing. But the fact that this particular death might have been prevented – had neonatal care not depended so heavily on charity, had the NHS not failed to fund more than two-thirds of the healthcare babies need – is unforgivable.Mercifully, the dystopian healthcare scenario I’ve just described does not exist in the UK today. Although paediatric care is undeniably overstretched, it is at least regarded as a core, bedrock NHS service.Dr Rachel Clarke is an NHS specialist in palliative medicine and the winner of the 2025 Women’s prize for nonfiction Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses the state of palliative care in the UK.
The author is a palliative medicine specialist in the NHS.
The author won the 2025 Women’s prize for nonfiction.
The article highlights the need for better end-of-life care.
The author describes a dystopian healthcare scenario.

clusters.title: Waiting for the all-clear: how medics and villagers rallied when Ebola returned to DRC
clusters.neutral_headline: Medics and Villagers Rally Against Ebola in the DRC

items.title: Waiting for the all-clear: how medics and villagers rallied when Ebola returned to DRC
items.standfirst: If no new cases are reported in Bulape by early December, the country will have vanquished its 16th outbreak of the deadly virus since it was discovered there in 1976His two-year-old daughter died first, then his mother, then his wife. But Bope Mpona Héritier still had no idea what illness had taken their lives. Then the 25-year-old also began to develop symptoms. When his blood was tested and sent to the Democratic Republic of the Congo’s capital, Kinshasa, the results confirmed he had the Ebola virus.“I felt pain everywhere,” he says. “I had a migraine, a sharp pain in my eyes and throat, and I was vomiting. I couldn’t eat anything because I had no appetite, so I lost a lot of weight.” Continue reading...
items.content: If no new cases are reported in Bulape by early December, the country will have vanquished its 16th outbreak of the deadly virus since it was discovered there in 1976His two-year-old daughter died first, then his mother, then his wife. When his blood was tested and sent to the Democratic Republic of the Congo’s capital, Kinshasa, the results confirmed he had the Ebola virus.“I felt pain everywhere,” he says. “I had a migraine, a sharp pain in my eyes and throat, and I was vomiting. I couldn’t eat anything because I had no appetite, so I lost a lot of weight.” Continue reading...

clusters.title: No link between paracetamol in pregnancy and autism or ADHD in children, review finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Review Finds No Link Between Paracetamol and Autism/ADHD

items.title: No link between paracetamol in pregnancy and autism or ADHD in children, review finds
items.standfirst: Wide-ranging review finds no convincing connection after Trump said women should ‘fight like hell’ to avoid painkillerA wide-ranging review into paracetamol use by pregnant women has found no convincing link between the common painkiller and the chances of children being diagnosed with autism and ADHD.Publication of the work was fast-tracked to provide prospective mothers and their doctors with reliable information after the Trump administration urged pregnant women to avoid paracetamol – also known as acetaminophen or Tylenol – claiming it was contributing to rising rates of autism. Continue reading...

clusters.title: It pays to support women’s health in the workplace | Letter
clusters.neutral_headline: Workplace Support for Women's Health is Important

items.title: It pays to support women’s health in the workplace | Letter
items.standfirst: Prof Geeta Nargund says employers need to take action on health inequality as research shows more than 32% of women aren’t receiving enough help to stay in workThe Keep Britain Working review has shed valuable light on the number of working-age adults in the UK falling out of work due to ill health (Fixing Britain’s worklessness crisis will cost employers £6bn a year, report says, 5 November). As part of this, we should also specifically acknowledge the impact of women’s health issues and the role of employers in addressing these.In a report by the NHS Confederation in partnership with our foundation, we found that an estimated £11bn is lost annually due to absenteeism for gynaecological conditions alone. And earlier this year, our research found that 15% of women report having to change to part-time work and 14% have had to quit work due to women’s health conditions. Furthermore, 32% of women reported that they aren’t receiving enough support for their health issues from their employers. Continue reading...
items.content: Prof Geeta Nargund says employers need to take action on health inequality as research shows more than 32% of women aren’t receiving enough help to stay in workThe Keep Britain Working review has shed valuable light on the number of working-age adults in the UK falling out of work due to ill health (Fixing Britain’s worklessness crisis will cost employers £6bn a year, report says, 5 November). As part of this, we should also specifically acknowledge the impact of women’s health issues and the role of employers in addressing these.In a report by the NHS Confederation in partnership with our foundation, we found that an estimated £11bn is lost annually due to absenteeism for gynaecological conditions alone. And earlier this year, our research found that 15% of women report having to change to part-time work and 14% have had to quit work due to women’s health conditions. Furthermore, 32% of women reported that they aren’t receiving enough support for their health issues from their employers. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Research shows over 32% of women lack sufficient workplace health support.
The Keep Britain Working review highlights worklessness due to ill health.
An estimated £11 billion is lost annually due to gynaecological conditions.
15% of women changed to part-time work due to health conditions.
14% of women quit work due to women's health conditions.

clusters.title: Older people playing pickleball isn’t risky – it’s medicine | Letter
clusters.neutral_headline: Pickleball is Beneficial for Older People

items.title: Older people playing pickleball isn’t risky – it’s medicine | Letter
items.standfirst: I’d rather see active, smiling people with the odd strain than a generation glued to the sofa, says physiotherapist Christien BirdSo what if a 2020 study found that 91% of pickleball injuries involved people aged over 50 (You should act your age – at least when it comes to exercise. Here’s why, 3 November)? Most pickleball players are over 50! I’d rather see active, smiling people with the odd strain than a generation glued to the sofa. The real health crisis isn’t overexercising – it’s inactivity.Fitness is the biggest predictor of long-term health and independence. Ageing is inevitable, but fragility is not. Women in particular face an accelerated loss of bone and muscle through menopause, yet 84% of inactive women going through menopause want to be more active and 90% would get active if advised by a professional. There is still a societal acceptance that it is OK to be a fragile older lady behind a Zimmer frame with no bum in her trousers. Continue reading...
items.content: I’d rather see active, smiling people with the odd strain than a generation glued to the sofa, says physiotherapist Christien BirdSo what if a 2020 study found that 91% of pickleball injuries involved people aged over 50 (You should act your age – at least when it comes to exercise. Here’s why, 3 November)? Most pickleball players are over 50! I’d rather see active, smiling people with the odd strain than a generation glued to the sofa. The real health crisis isn’t overexercising – it’s inactivity.Fitness is the biggest predictor of long-term health and independence. Ageing is inevitable, but fragility is not. Women in particular face an accelerated loss of bone and muscle through menopause, yet 84% of inactive women going through menopause want to be more active and 90% would get active if advised by a professional. There is still a societal acceptance that it is OK to be a fragile older lady behind a Zimmer frame with no bum in her trousers. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article argues pickleball is beneficial for older people.
A 2020 study found 91% of pickleball injuries involved people over 50.
The author believes inactivity is a greater health crisis.
Fitness is the biggest predictor of long-term health and independence.
84% of inactive menopausal women want to be more active.

clusters.title: She left her desk job and walked 3,541 miles from Mexico to Canada: ‘Give yourself permission’
clusters.neutral_headline: Woman Hikes 3,541 Miles from Mexico to Canada

items.title: She left her desk job and walked 3,541 miles from Mexico to Canada: ‘Give yourself permission’
items.standfirst: Jessica Guo hiked 30 miles a day, becoming the first woman to continuously hike two historic trails in a single seasonJessica Guo had only slept for two and a half hours on an overnight bus when she arrived at the Mexico-US border near Lordsburg, New Mexico, in April. Out of the window she saw a flat, shadeless landscape. First-day jitters had Guo questioning what she was doing there.The former consultant had left corporate America to attempt something no woman had completed: a single, continuous hike of the Continental Divide Trail (CDT) and the Great Divide Trail (GDT) in a single season. Continue reading...
items.content: Jessica Guo hiked 30 miles a day, becoming the first woman to continuously hike two historic trails in a single seasonJessica Guo had only slept for two and a half hours on an overnight bus when she arrived at the Mexico-US border near Lordsburg, New Mexico, in April. Out of the window she saw a flat, shadeless landscape. First-day jitters had Guo questioning what she was doing there.The former consultant had left corporate America to attempt something no woman had completed: a single, continuous hike of the Continental Divide Trail (CDT) and the Great Divide Trail (GDT) in a single season. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Jessica Guo hiked 3,541 miles from Mexico to Canada.
She hiked the Continental Divide Trail and Great Divide Trail.
She became the first woman to hike both trails continuously.
She hiked approximately 30 miles each day.
She left a desk job to pursue the hike.

clusters.title: What we lose when we surrender care to algorithms | Eric Reinhart
clusters.neutral_headline: What we lose when we surrender care to algorithms

items.title: What we lose when we surrender care to algorithms | Eric Reinhart
items.standfirst: A dangerous faith in AI is sweeping American healthcare – with consequences for the basis of society itselfThe computer interrupted while Pamela was still speaking. I had accompanied her – my dear friend – to a recent doctor’s appointment. She is in her 70s, lives alone while navigating multiple chronic health issues, and has been getting short of breath climbing the front stairs to her apartment. In the exam room, she spoke slowly and self-consciously, the way people often do when they are trying to describe their bodies and anxieties to strangers. Midway through her description of how she had been feeling, the doctor clicked his mouse and a block of text began to bloom across the computer monitor.The clinic had adopted an artificial-intelligence scribe, and it was transcribing and summarizing the conversation in real time. It was also highlighting keywords, suggesting diagnostic possibilities and providing billing codes. The doctor, apparently satisfied that his computer had captured an adequate description of Pamela’s chief complaint and symptoms, turned away from us and began reviewing the text on the screen as Pamela kept speaking. Continue reading...
items.content: A dangerous faith in AI is sweeping American healthcare – with consequences for the basis of society itselfThe computer interrupted while Pamela was still speaking. I had accompanied her – my dear friend – to a recent doctor’s appointment. She is in her 70s, lives alone while navigating multiple chronic health issues, and has been getting short of breath climbing the front stairs to her apartment. In the exam room, she spoke slowly and self-consciously, the way people often do when they are trying to describe their bodies and anxieties to strangers. Midway through her description of how she had been feeling, the doctor clicked his mouse and a block of text began to bloom across the computer monitor.The clinic had adopted an artificial-intelligence scribe, and it was transcribing and summarizing the conversation in real time. It was also highlighting keywords, suggesting diagnostic possibilities and providing billing codes. The doctor, apparently satisfied that his computer had captured an adequate description of Pamela’s chief complaint and symptoms, turned away from us and began reviewing the text on the screen as Pamela kept speaking. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses the impact of AI in healthcare.
The author accompanied a friend to a doctor's appointment.

The AI transcribed and summarized the conversation.
The AI also suggested diagnoses and billing codes.

clusters.title: If you’re feeling anxious, take a moment to pause before pouring that glass of wine | Diane Young
clusters.neutral_headline: Anxiety and Alcohol: Understanding the Connection and Coping Strategies

items.title: If you’re feeling anxious, take a moment to pause before pouring that glass of wine | Diane Young
items.standfirst: Anxiety can disrupt relationships, affect sleep and lead to harmful coping behaviours. Early awareness is crucialThe modern mind is a column where experts discuss mental health issues they are seeing in their workWhen Mia*, 35, walks into my office, she looks composed and ready to start her day fresh with a counselling session. But having seen Mia for almost half a year now, I know she masks the truth behind her polished facade, and I notice the subtle tension in her shoulders that gives it away.Mia tells me that the night before, she had poured herself “just one glass of wine” to unwind after a long day. One glass became two, then three. It’s a pattern she has grown used to; a quiet ritual that helps her “switch off” from the racing thoughts that flood her mind when the day finally slows down. Continue reading...
items.content: Anxiety can disrupt relationships, affect sleep and lead to harmful coping behaviours. Early awareness is crucialThe modern mind is a column where experts discuss mental health issues they are seeing in their workWhen Mia*, 35, walks into my office, she looks composed and ready to start her day fresh with a counselling session. But having seen Mia for almost half a year now, I know she masks the truth behind her polished facade, and I notice the subtle tension in her shoulders that gives it away.Mia tells me that the night before, she had poured herself “just one glass of wine” to unwind after a long day. One glass became two, then three. It’s a pattern she has grown used to; a quiet ritual that helps her “switch off” from the racing thoughts that flood her mind when the day finally slows down. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Anxiety can disrupt relationships, affect sleep, and lead to harmful coping behaviors, according to experts.
A counselor notes that clients often use alcohol to unwind and quiet racing thoughts after long days.
One client, Mia, admits to drinking multiple glasses of wine to cope with anxiety and stress.
The article emphasizes the importance of early awareness of anxiety and its impact on daily life.
Experts discuss mental health issues and offer insights into managing anxiety and related behaviors.
